I understand what you are saying. Cops are trained to shoot for the center 
ring - because that is the widest target on the human body. Shooting a leg, 
or shooting a weapon out of someone's hand, while they are charging you is 
highly unrealistic -- and even if you did have the skill to hit a small 
moving target with a handgun, your adrenaline would make it a coin toss.

However, consider this. There were multiple men covering the suspect - with 
a combination of lethal and "less" lethal options. Some of those men had 
rifles. The target was stationary and closer than fifty feet. Shooting a 
suspect in the lower portion of his body at that range, with that weapon 
type, is not difficult at all. The risk of missing your target is mitigated 
by the fact that other officers are backing you up - ready to spray a hail 
storm of bullets (as are you) if you miss, and the subject decides to 
charge.

Now, I grant you that police policy, which is different depending on 
jurisdiction, typically does not back-up "shooting-to-wound" actions (in 
order to discourage the dangerous practice). But considering how many other 
options had already failed, the "reasonable man" could be expected to 
consider it as an option, and that is a valid defense for deviating from 
policy - backed up by a mountain of case law. 

Do you agree?

http://m.dailykos.com/story/2015/04/28/1380326/-Albuquerque-DA-told-to-fear-for-her-safety-courtesy-police?detail=email
Albuquerque DA told to fear for her safety, courtesy police
Apr 27, 2015 5:29pm PDT 
"....more scary news from the Duke City, and it's for real. Not from any of 
its famous TV series.
The county district attorney overseeing Albuquerque Police has gone on the 
record in the ABQ Free Press, saying that sympathetic police have informed 
her that others on the force may intend to do her physical harm. She told 
the recently established alternative weekly:

"I don’t think they’re going to kill me, but I have been told to fear for 
my safety,"
The DA, Kari Brandenburg, has been under massive pressure from the APD 
thanks to her decision to charge two officers with murder in the death of 
homeless camper James Boyd last spring. The image of Boyd being shot down 
while retreating from police in the foothills east of the city went viral, 
leading to major demonstrations locally and heightened interest shortly 
thereafter when the U.S. Department of Justice issued a scathing report on 
years of excessive force by the APD.
More recently, in what was perceived as an act of preemptive retaliation 
before Brandenburg had even filed the murder charges, police announced that 
they were investigating her for intimidation and bribery of witnesses in 
relation to a burglary case involving her son. In spite of that, 
Brandenburg maintained her cool, answering those accusations and not 
backing down on the murder charges.

In any event, since that time a judge has decided the appearance of 
conflict of interest was too much and ordered Brandenburg off the Boyd 
murder case. That might actually have been to the detriment of the accused 
cops, since she then turned around and appointed a special prosecutor who 
has an equally tough reputation (and happens to be the wife of a state 
Supreme Court justice).

A lesser known, but possibly as disturbing, case of APD abuse is that of 
the late 2010 death of civil rights attorney Mary Han. APD quickly ruled it 
a suicide, but there was much more to the story (again courtesy the Free 
Press):

Han was prominent among civil rights and criminal defense attorneys, but 
was especially prominent for her success in bringing lawsuits against the 
Albuquerque Police Department, against which she had won judgments. News of 
Han’s death began to spread via texts and phone calls among APD officers 
and officials. Within an hour of [her law partner's] 911 call, every one of 
APD’s deputy chiefs was on the scene.
The story concluded with a view from a retired APD forensic investigator:
"One of two things happened that day. Either it was an absolute case of 
total incompetence by everyone involved, or it was cover-up. Those are the 
only two possibilities."
To date that investigation remains, in my opinion, possibly the creepiest 
cover-up ever perpetrated by APD. (The author of that piece, David Correia, 
had his own brush with APD in the past year. He was arrested on a ludicrous 
charge of felony assault on an officer at a city council meeting.)
Then there is another heartbreaking story, that of the 2011 fatal shooting 
of a mentally ill young man, Christopher Torres, reported in the New 
Yorker. Unlike Boyd, Torres' parents were well-connected in city 
government. But that did not help avoid the insanely tragic ending of his 
life and the blue-washing of its account. As usual, the local media were 
all too happy to regurgitate the predictable lies put forth in the APD's 
version of the death:

The Torres family learned how Christopher died from watching the news the 
next day. At a press conference, the department’s chief public-safety 
officer said that two officers had tried to arrest Christopher at home, 
but, when he resisted and grabbed a gun from one of them, the officers felt 
that their lives were in danger. The local television stations ran an 
unflattering picture of Christopher with his eyes bugged out. One station 
reported that the “police suspected Torres is responsible for several 
violent road rage incidents around the city.” The police department said 
publicly that Christopher had a lengthy criminal history, which was untrue.
And so it has gone for years and years. For deeper historical perspective, 
this Weekly Alibi article (also penned by Correia) describes "an internal 
APD report showing that its officers killed 15 people between 1987 and 
1991, a number that exceeded fatal shootings over the same period in 
Tucson, Austin, El Paso, Colorado Springs and Tulsa combined. Then, as now, 
the shooting victims included unarmed suspects." The story reveals that, 
aside from heightened public awareness, little has changed over the years.
Even after the nationwide outcry over Boyd, the D.O.J. intervention and 
Brandenburg's prosecution efforts, the dark forces within the APD are 
essentially just flipping off anyone in the community that stands up to 
them. Their tactic of arresting Correia on phony assault charges (which 
they dropped a few months later) appeared amateurish and stupid. But their 
ability to rule by fear of force remains unabated.

We can only hope and pray that, with an official with Brandenburg's rank 
openly expressing her safety concerns, something has got to give.

Update: Ten years in the community and this is my first time on the rec 
list, thank you all !

I know I might sound like a monster by supporting them but hear me out. 
During Army officer training, we were taught "Shout, Shove, Shoot" 

-First you shout and tell the target to stand down.
-If that doesn't work, you can "shove" which is to raise your weapon or use 
other non lethal methods.
-Finally, if they don't comply, they have to shoot.

The APD did follow all this procedure giving him tons of time to stand 
down. The target pulls out something from his bag. You may just think that 
"oh he only has a knife and they have guns" but you have to be aware of 
IEDs. Every year 2,500 Americans die from IED's and the CO of this squad 
doesn't want to risk this. There have been too many cases where American 
authorities were very lax and the next thing you know, they all end up 
blown up.

In the end, they gave the suspect tons of time to stand down. Instead, the 
suspect quickly reaches for something in his backpack after being 
threatened. The only conclusion the APD could make is that he is up to no 
good and whatever is coming out of that bag is probably a weapon. In the 
heat of a life threatening moment, you usually don't have time to take a 
closer look and see what it is or think of a more rational solution. Was 
the target life-threatening? You always have to assume so or you will be 
the one eating the dirt.﻿

I've watched this maybe 50 times. If I may I'll tell you what I saw & have 
learned.

The guy was a loner. Terrible upbringing. He inherited a mental illness 
from his mother & was abused by his father & other carers. So he was both 
born wrong & corrupted as he was being raised.

In his youth he committed some sex crimes, full details unknown, but I've 
read nothing to say violence was involved. He was sentenced to 10 years in 
prison, when in retrospect he should have received mental health care in an 
institution. Apparently he was a changed person when he was released.

He had the potential to be violent, & had caused harm to others. Crimes for 
which he had been again punished. But he had also been committed to mental 
institutions. He sought & gained his release, & retreated from society. 
That's what led him to be camping alone in the foothills.

I'm not defending the man, I'm striving to give some background. He had 
done some weird things. Things no sane person would have done. He had been 
convicted of some sex offenses, but he does not appear to have been a 
serial sex offender. He had committed some violent crimes, but he does not 
appear to have been an inherently violent person. Basically he was a deeply 
disturbed individual who sought solitude.

On the day in question police were informed that a suspicious individual 
was illegally camping in the foothills. The first two officers on the scene 
could not get Boyd just to leave. He was holding a knife or knives & 
verbally rambling. They called for support.

A standoff ensued, lasting between three & five hours depending on which 
reports you read. The APD did not deploy one of their four specialist 
crisis intervention officers, but there was an officer there that had had 
about 40 hours training in crisis intervention. Whatever transpired during 
the standoff, Boyd eventually agreed to surrender peacefully.

This is evidenced by him saying
"Don't change up the agreement, I'm going to try & walk now."
"I can keep you safe, alright?"
"I'm worried about safety, I'm not a fucking murderer"

He was saying these & other things whilst putting on his backpack, picking 
up a thermos in one hand & a bag in his other. He had turned away from the 
police as he was doing these latter things. It seemed like a peaceful 
arrest was about to be made, but as he turned back everything changed.

Without verbal command, the flash-bang was thrown. Boyd hadn't even 
completed one step. This is immediately followed by the verbal command (not 
to Boyd) to "Do it". The dog was immediately released, then the flash-bang 
exploded & the officers started shouting orders to Boyd to "get on the 
ground."

In seconds Boyd had gone from receiving assurances from the police that 
they would not change up the agreement or do anything "stupid", to being 
assaulted in three ways. The flash-bag, the charging dog, & the advancing 
officers shouting orders.

He reacted by dropping everything he was carrying, & reaching for a couple 
of small pocket knives to defend himself. The absolute key point is that he 
never advanced on the officers whilst he had the knives in his hands. They 
were purely drawn for defense against the dog.

I've speculated on what Boyd was going to do, but I know what he wasn't 
doing, & that was threatening the police when he was fatally shot.

He may have posed a threat earlier, he might have posed a threat later. But 
at the time when he was surrendering he posed no threat, & at the key point 
when he turned to his left, when he was either about to "get on the ground" 
or start fleeing, no officer was in danger of being harmed.

It was at this point that the officer nearest to the dog handler opened 
fire. The officer with the helmet-cam fired the last three shots. The 
officer with the taser rifle may also have fired a round, it's difficult to 
tell, but he did not shoot first.

What's chilling for me is the cry of "Booya!", just after Boyd's skull 
crashes onto the rock he fell on to. For at least one of those officers 
this was a exciting experience.

What follows is just sickening. Boyd wasn't dead, but he was pleading. He 
first says in response to orders to drop the knives
"Can't move"
As the order continues to be shouted he says
"Please don't hurt me. I can't move"

The response of the police was to hit him with three bean bag shots. 
(Remember they outnumber him six to one) Even then, after he doesn't 
respond, they can't garner the courage to approach his prone body. They 
chose to release the dog again.

For me a key problem in US society is that firearms embolden people to take 
aggressive actions they otherwise would not. The police are further 
emboldened by the authority they're granted. And when, like with the APD, 
they're trained to shoot first, fatal mistakes are inevitable.

Unlike most who are screaming for the heads of these officers, I've thought 
deeply on this incident. I do believe the police acted cowardly. I'm 
certain their final assault on Boyd was premeditated & I do think the 
shooting was unjustified

But if this was murder, then they were trained to murder. The killer or 
killers did not get up that morning with the intention of shooting someone. 
Therefore malice & premeditation can never be proved, & murder charges 
would fail.

But a crime was committed here by the police that resulted in a person's 
death. Those directly responsible must be held accountable, & those 
secondarily responsible have to be admonished.

Boyd will be buried this Sunday. All right thinking people of Albuquerque 
will show their disgust at this senseless taking of life by attending the 
funeral. Others will just attend because of personal grievances or for 
anarchistic reasons.

But the US needs to start examining how other nations manage to police 
their populous without shooting & killing people.

Where I live in England & Wales, population 56 million plus, our armed 
police (We do have some, they're specially trained) killed nobody in 2013. 
They killed 9 people in the previous four years & we examined all 9 of 
those killing in minute detail. One sparked the London Riots. One or two 
I'm sure were unjustified. But in general our police receive respect 
because they give respect. In the USA it seems the police demand respect.

Sorry for the long post. I had a head full of information & some opinions. 
I striven to check that my information is correct. My opinions should carry 
no weight. They're just my way of chatting. ﻿

+Jordan Gabrielle If he had pulled a firearm instead of a knife, maybe my 
opinion would be somewhat different, but he did not. The officer had a 
rifle fixed on him even before he pulled the knife. I apologize for the 
confusion about my comment about the "high powered rifle", the point I was 
trying to make is that gun tends to trump knife pretty much 100% of the 
time. If knives were a viable option against guns (pistols, rifles, 
shotguns, or anything), The gun would have gone the way of the crossbow 
centuries ago. 

The fact that a knife can be lethal in many situations is irrelevant to 
this particular situation. Not only were there three rifles trained on the 
suspect during the entire confrontation, they opened fire AFTER he turned 
his back to retreat. And again, he didn't brandish the weapon until after 
he was assaulted (and I use the term assault because if I ever threw a 
flash grenade, however non-lethal it may be, at  police officer, that is 
sure as hell the term they would use) with the flash bang. Before that 
happened the man was complying with the demands of the officers. The cops 
escalated the situation for no discernible reason. Perhaps the man showed a 
level of defiance in attempting to defend himself from what was (with video 
friggin' evidence) a threat to his life, but that does not justify the 
actions of the officers by any reasonable definition of the word. If the 
subjects in this video were regular citizens, this would unquestionably be 
considered murder. 

(EDIT: I also feel I should throw this in there as well. I know my response 
comes across as pretty passionate, but I do not mean to channel anger at 
you, Jordan. All things considered, you seem like a pretty reasonable dude 
((especially by YouTube standards)) that happens to have a different 
opinion than mine. My anger is directed toward the police that I feel have 
abused their authority. Not you, yourself)

+Jordan Gabrielle
"Taking out the knives was an act of defiance and aggression"
Taking out the knives was a confused mentally impaired man's attempt at 
self-defense.
A tragic choice, yes.

+louis joseph Quino I know this is youtube so I don't expect real 
discussion from most, but grow up and at least try to have a real 
conversation. I do not want to justify their "excuses" or their 
"kill[ing]", but yes, I think they were justified in shooting him. And no, 
I am not a police officer nor am I advocate of blood thirsty violence.
+Tee F I actually agree with a lot of what you say, I don't think using the 
flash grenade was appropriate at all and I do hope there is repercussion 
for that. Yes there were a fair amount of ifs in my statement, I am 
specifically defending the officer who shot the man. If the man would have 
brought out a blunt weapon or put up his fists and charged the officer than 
certainly shooting him would be excessive force. Knives are incredibly 
dangerous weapons, they can do just as much damage as a gun, at close range 
(which the one officer was), if the man had pulled out a sidearm than you 
would definitely say they were right to shoot him. Taking out the knives 
was an act of defiance and aggression (after not getting on the ground like 
they asked). I also don't understand this high powered rifles vs knives 
question, it would have made no difference if he had used pistol. The 
officer countered lethal force with lethal force in defense of his fellow 
officer.

EDIT: And just to be clear, I think this is a tragedy, I do not wish nor 
celebrate death for anyone, but again, police brutality and excessive force 
are very real in the world we live, and this is not an example of either.

+Jordan Gabrielle Fuucking idiot. You want to justify their excuses to

for three armored men wielding rifles, tasers, tear gas, flash bangs, and a 
dangerous animal. You bring up a lot of what ifs. What if the taser didn't

option against high powered rifles, why do we have high powered rifles?

The biggest question, however, is why the hell did they throw a friggin'

was

When this happened, about 25% of APD officers were trained in crisis 
intervention– now committing to reach 100% by November. The goal is to be 
able to de-escalate situations before they become violent. 

But, if you watch this video, with or without context, it's obvious that 
the police officers escalated a then non-violent "negotiation" into a 
full-on violent crisis. Whether you're completely mentally stable or have 
serious issues, few people are going to react rationally when a group of 
people with their guns raised throw a surprise flashbang at them. That 
triggers adrenaline release and fight-or-flight takes over. That is an 
involuntary process that was wholly initiated by the police. We can't talk 
about whether a rational person would hit the ground or grab a knife, 
because rationality has been removed from the equation. 

So, I'm left wondering, does it really take crisis intervention training 
for police officers, or anyone, to realize that the actions taken by these 
officers were the cause of the violence that lead to what looks a lot like 
the execution of James Boyd? It's common knowledge that pointing a gun at 
someone severely affects their ability to make rational decisions. Then, 
the flashbang: should we be surprised when a device that is meant to 
confuse and disorient actually confuses and disorients? Barring the 
revelation of some very bizarre extenuating circumstances, these policemen 
aggressively backed Mr. Boyd into a corner and murdered him.﻿

ALBUQUERQUE — James Boyd, a homeless man camping in the Sandia Foothills 
here, could hear the commands of the police officers who were trying to 
move him out.
The problem was that Mr. Boyd, 38, had a history of mental illness, and so 
was living in a different reality, one in which he was a federal agent and 
not someone to be bossed around.
“Don’t attempt to give me, the Department of Defense, another directive,” 
he told the officers. A short while later, the police shot and killed him, 
saying he had pulled out two knives and threatened their lives.

Personally I think emotion is running too high in many of the responses to 
the video in this column.

I agree that it turned out to be a very regrettable and premature 
aggressive action on the part of the police, and that is very sad indeed, 
b/c it cost a man his life. I think they acted wrongly, but I have a bit 
more sympathy than many seem to. Everyone seems to be ignoring all 
negatives on the part of the drifter that put his life needlessly in 
danger. He did NOT heed the directives of law enforcement (and didn't have 
a compelling reason not to), he WAS armed, AND he seemed to possibly be 
fumbling in his pockets for who knows what? A gun? grenade? etc.

Am I justifying the incident? No. Am I glad the FBI is investigating the 
matter? Yes. Do I think it automatically makes the police officers pure 
evil? No.﻿

+sometimesoon What's funny is that I almost added a quip about our 
pseudo-democracy, but the truth is we still function as a democracy in 
spirit. While it may be confusing how I worded it, when I mentioned elected 
officials and went on to say that we decide the rules, I meant it to mean 
that we do so through voting and election of said public officials who 
designate policy and enforce rules in line with the beliefs of the voters 
who elected them (i.e. along party lines, or agreement with their election 
platform).

That said, those cops were under the jurisdiction of the city in which they 
work. Large PDs like that tend to take a lot of input from the community on 
policy (most have civilian boards on which a number of officers can sit, 
and the rest is civilian members of the community) through voting and/or 
recommendations. The sessions for these boards are, typically, open to the 
public and allow a forum for citizens in the know to attend and demand 
attention being given to certain issues. That said, the DA in this case is 
an elected official and is, therefore, beholden to the citizenry that 
continues to re-elect her. If she does something they disagree with, she 
will not be elected again - and in a lot of areas can actually be recalled 
during term.

That said, we both know that the number of active citizens in even a large 
city is minuscule. Sometimes as little as ten percent of a community will 
decide such important stuff, and they tend to be middle class white people 
(which begins a conversation of community organizers and voters rights that 
doesn't belong here).
